title: 110_hr5513
content: The Act is titled the "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" and aims to strengthen state laws regarding tobacco product sales to individuals under the age of 18. For fiscal year 2010 and subsequent years, the Secretary can grant funds under section 1921 only if the state has a law prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18 and the purchase by individuals under 18. The law prohibits individuals under 18 from purchasing or possessing tobacco products in public places. Law enforcement must notify parents if a minor is caught buying or possessing tobacco. Within 180 days of the State law taking effect, retail tobacco distributors must inform their employees about the prohibition of selling tobacco products to individuals under 18 years old. Within 180 days of the State law taking effect, retail tobacco distributors must inform their employees about the prohibition of selling tobacco products to individuals under 18 years old. An employer shall not be in violation if they rely on valid proof of age or implement a compliance program. The prohibition of selling tobacco products to individuals under 18 may result in civil penalties and community service for violators. Some states have delayed the requirement for legislative sessions in fiscal years 2010 and 2011. The funding agreement for a grant under section 1921 requires states to establish goals for reducing retailer violations of tobacco laws, with specific violation rate targets for fiscal years 2010 and 2011. The funding agreement for a grant under section 1921 requires states to enforce the law, with decreasing violation rate targets from 19 percent in fiscal year 2011 to 10 percent in fiscal year 2020 and subsequent years. The funding agreement for a grant under section 1921 mandates states to enforce laws to reduce underage access to tobacco products. This includes conducting annual random inspections for compliance and submitting reports to the Secretary. The state must annually report to the Secretary on their enforcement activities to reduce underage access to tobacco products and their success in meeting established goals. The state must report annually to the Secretary on enforcement activities to reduce underage access to tobacco products. A grant under section 1921 allows the state to use individuals under 18 for compliance testing with parental consent. The state can use individuals under 18 for compliance testing with parental consent and direct supervision during inspections. State settlement proceeds must be used according to a funding agreement for a grant under section 1921. The Secretary must determine if a State has complied with specific requirements before granting funds under section 1921. If noncompliance is found, the State's allotment may be reduced starting from the first applicable fiscal year. The Secretary may reduce a State's allotment under section 1921 if noncompliance with specific requirements is found after notice and a hearing. The reduction amount is determined based on the fiscal year, such as 10 percent for fiscal year 2010 and 20 percent for fiscal year 2011. The Secretary can reduce a State's allotment under section 1921 for noncompliance with requirements, with reduction percentages varying by fiscal year: 10% for 2010, 20% for 2011, 30% for 2012, and 40% for 2013 onwards. If a State is not compliant with certain subsections, the Secretary can reduce the allotment by 10% for the fiscal year. The Secretary will also assist States in implementing State laws by developing guidelines by January 1, 2009. The Secretary will develop model legislative language and provide technical assistance for enacting laws by January 1, 2009. The term 'first applicable fiscal year' is defined as fiscal year 2012 for certain States and fiscal year 2010 for others. The amendment made by subsection (a) applies to the first applicable fiscal year and each subsequent fiscal year. The provisions of section 1926 of the Public Health Service Act apply to fiscal years preceding the first applicable fiscal year. The term "first applicable fiscal year" is defined in subsection (g) of section 1926. The term "first applicable fiscal year" is defined in subsection (g) of section 1926 of the Public Health Service Act. SEC. 3. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF INGREDIENTS. The Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act is amended to make ingredient information accessible to the public online within 48 hours of submission to the Secretary.
